title: Berkshire Lieutenants Step Into Spotlight at Annual Meeting
summary: Ajit Jain and Greg Abel, two men most likely to succeed Warren Buffett, discussed conglomerate's business operations. OMAHA, Neb.-The two men most likely to succeed Warren Buffett as chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. took their turns in the spotlight at the company's annual meeting Saturday.

title: Tech Executive Charts Old and New Path to Vice Presidency
summary: David Blake is launching a campaign to bring back the days of electing the veep by popular vote. PROVO, Utah-A bus stop on the campus of Brigham Young University is where David Blake began his quest to bring back the days of independently electing the next U.S. vice president, namely him.

title: Sen. Enzi Won't Seek Re-Election
summary: The Republican from Wyoming says he wants to focus on the national debt. WASHINGTON-Sen. Mike Enzi (R., Wyo.) said Saturday that he wouldn't run for re-election in 2020, the latest Senate Republican to announce he would retire rather than seek to keep his seat.

title: Three Employees Feared Dead in Explosion at Illinois Silicone Plant
summary: Resume Subscription. WAUKEGAN, Ill.-An explosion and fire at an Illinois silicone factory was believed to have killed three people, authorities said Saturday, as they recovered the body of one victim while suspending the search for the other two.

title: Longtime Queens D.A. Richard Brown Dies at 86
summary: He presided over an era that saw the borough's crime rates decline dramatically. Queens District Attorney Richard A. Brown, a Democrat who served in that position for nearly 28 years, died Friday night at the age of 86, according to his office.

title: Air Force Base's Recovery Stalls as Congress Lingers on Disaster Aid
It Might Be Time to Move the NBA's 3-Point Line
summary: The game is changing. The rules aren't. A new book wonders if basketball could use some bolder thinking.. By any objective measure, it was a crazy idea: a strip of paint slapped on the basketball court that suddenly made certain shots worth an extra point. But this strange innovation turned out to be a stroke of genius. And the 3-point line wouldn't exist if not for someone willing to indulge some wild experiments to make the game more popular.

title: For Flood-Hit Farmers on Missouri River, Sand Is the Next Challenge
summary: In areas where floodwaters have receded, farmers are left to deal with piles of sand, debris on their fields. Since record flooding sent a torrent of water down the Missouri River in March, many farmers are now dealing with another challenge-sand. Lots and lots of it.

title: 'They Brutalize Us': Women Struggle With Violence in Mexico
summary: Violence against women has been met with indifference and impunity, rights groups say, as the problem only gets worse. For months after 22-year-old Lesvy Berlín was found strangled to death in a phone booth on a Mexican university campus, police told her parents that their daughter had committed suicide.

title: Shake Shack Results Were Too Sunny
summary: Restaurant chain beat sales estimates thanks to some unusually warm weather, and shares fell. Blame it on the sunshine.

title: Tony Nominations Have Made 'Hadestown' Hottest Ticket in Town
summary: An unlikely hit musical is challenging Broadway conventions. By conventional Broadway measures, "Hadestown" might not have the makings of a hit show. A jazz-inflected musical based on a Greek mythological tale of a trip to the underworld, it lacks the kind of instant selling points as other shows, such as a story drawn from a popular movie or a score of jukebox favorites.

title: What to Watch at the Kentucky Derby
summary: The Run for the Roses appears wide open, but the white-haired King of the Triple Crown might have something to say. The Kentucky Derby is supposed to be a difficult race to handicap, with a field of up to 20 horses, contested at an unfamiliar distance (1 1/4 miles) to still maturing 3-year-olds.

title: Amy Poehler on Being in Charge-and Liking It
summary: Directing her first film at 47, for Netflix, the producer talks about the power of middle-aged women in an industry geared to youth. In mid-career, Amy Poehler has just directed her first film, "Wine Country," a comedy about six middle-aged women who take a trip to Napa to celebrate a 50th birthday. The story was inspired by birthday trips she has taken with friends. "It's not like we got chased by a bear or picked up by a drug lord," Ms. Poehler says. "I like exploring female friendship at this age."

title: Gemma Ward Wishes Fast Fashion Was Less Prevalent
summary: The Australian-born model on her go-to travel ensemble, her wish for more sustainable fashion practices and the best career advice she's ever gotten. This is part of a series of interviews with the four models featured in our May issue fashion portfolio. See the shoot here, and read interviews with Karen Elson, Alek Wek and Amber Valletta.

title: Victims of Stanford Ponzi Scheme Make a Final Push Against Banks
summary: Lawsuit from investors and hedge funds seeks settlements from TD Bank and four other institutions. In the decade since R. Allen Stanford's international financial empire was exposed as a fiction, investors in his Ponzi scheme have recouped just a tiny fraction of the life savings many of them lost.

title: Uber Wants to Be the Uber of Everything-But Can It Make a Profit?
summary: The ride-hailing company, headed for its IPO, aims to dominate the world of transportation, from food delivery to freight. It's still not making any money.. In Uber's vision of the future, most people won't own cars. Riders will hop on electric bikes and scooters for short distances, and summon cars with drivers for longer rides. Takeout dinner will become a vestige, replaced by hand-delivered meals. Garages will empty and parking lots will be ripped up and transformed into grassy parks.

title: Altitude Training in London Requires Extra Effort
summary: After leaving a job in the City, a professional cyclist finds ways to reduce his oxygen intake during rides and even when he's sleeping. Four years ago, Alex Richardson worked a 9-to-5 job, making a lavish salary by sitting at a desk in London tracking oil shipments. Today, at 29, he is a professional cyclist pushing his body with a particularly grueling type of training: starving himself of oxygen.

title: 'Oscar Rejlander: Artist Photographer' Review: More Than High Camp
summary: The Victorian photographer is often snubbed for his overly sentimental themes, but in the technical realm he was a clear-eyed innovator.. Los Angeles

title: Writer Judith Viorst Finds Joy and Wisdom in Aging
summary: The author of classic children's books turns her attention to late life in her new collection of poems. Judith Viorst is best known as the author of books for children, especially "Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day," which has sold about four million copies since it was published in 1972. But she faced a different kind of challenge when she started writing the poems in her new book, "Nearing 90 and Other Comedies of Late Life." "In late life, there are a lot of tough things you're dealing with," says Ms. Viorst, who is 88. "You're thinking of moving to a retirement community with old people. You're trying to remember the punchline of a joke before you tell it. Ninety is not the new 60," she says. "In order to think about all the tough stuff, you can't pretend it doesn't exist and still write something hopeful and funny."

title: Music Superstars Are the New One Percenters
summary: Resume Subscription. A small number of superstars like Beyoncé and Taylor Swift is gobbling up an increasingly outsize share of concert-tour revenues, as music's biggest acts dominate the business like never before.

title: World Governments Test Minimum-Wage Raises
summary: Major economies consider trial and error to see at what threshold costs could outweigh benefits. FRANKFURT-From Athens to Seoul, governments around the world are increasing the minimum wage, seeking to assuage voter concerns over years of weak pay growth and rising inequality.

title: Thailand Crowns Its Newest King
summary: The elaborate ceremony precedes political drama as opposing parties prepare to form a government. BANGKOK-Thailand's king formally began his reign as the 10th monarch of the Chakri dynasty in an elaborate coronation ceremony steeped in centuries of tradition.

title: Passengers Safe After Plane Crashes Into River in Florida
summary: The charter plane with 143 on board was traveling from Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. JACKSONVILLE, Fla.-A charter plane carrying 143 people and traveling from Cuba to north Florida ended up in a river at the end of a runway Friday night, though no critical injuries or deaths were reported, officials said.

title: North Korea Fires Unidentified Short-Range Weapon
summary: The latest military provocation from Pyongyang comes amid stalled nuclear talks with Washington. SEOUL-North Korea fired a type of short-range weapon off the country's east coast on Saturday morning, according to South Korea's Defense Ministry, the latest military provocation from Pyongyang amid stalled nuclear talks with Washington.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: In a Tight Labor Market, Gig Workers Get Harder to Please
summary: Companies like Uber, Lyft, Postmates and Instacart could run out of manpower as high turnover plagues the side-hustle economy. Jason Noorzai has worked for eight different "gig economy" startups and services since 2015: Postmates, Doordash, Grubhub , Amazon Flex, Uber, Lyft, Field Agent and Deliv.

title: Sometimes 'Genius' Is Just Great Management
summary: Ayrton Senna lay out his leadership lessons in 'Principles of Race Driving': enter slowly, exit fast. Most elite drivers believe that in racing, there are moments to push and moments to throttle down. Ayrton Senna wasn't one of them.

title: Venezuela's Opposition Came Close to Ousting the President-but the Plan Fell Apart
summary: Regime insiders in talks with opposition are said to have lost confidence in the bid to remove Maduro. BOGOTÁ, Colombia-Venezuela's opposition came tantalizingly close to removing President Nicolás Maduro from power this week, according to more than a dozen people involved in talks to oust him.

title: Charlie Munger, Unplugged
summary: The investing legend and longtime deputy to Berkshire Hathaway's Warren Buffett holds court. Berkshire Hathaway Inc. Vice Chairman Charlie Munger, 95, spoke to Wall Street Journal reporters Nicole Friedman and Jason Zweig for six hours over dinner in his Los Angeles home on April 23. He covered a wide array of subjects. Here is an edited transcript from that conversation and a follow-up telephone discussion.

title: Exxon Mobil Sues Cuban Companies Over Seized Property
summary: The case is one of the first since the Trump administration lifted restrictions preventing such lawsuits. Exxon Mobil Corp. has sued two Cuban companies in a U.S. federal court under a newly revived provision that permits legal action by U.S. citizens or entities against companies doing business on property that was confiscated by the Cuban government.

title: Three Charged With Operating Illicit Dark-Web Marketplace
summary: U.S. prosecutors accuse German nationals of stealing $11 million in virtual currency; men face charges in their home country as well.. U.S. prosecutors charged three German nationals with operating an illicit marketplace on the dark web and then stealing roughly $11 million in virtual currency from its users.

title: Warren Buffett's Empire, in 194,300 Square Feet
summary: The billionaire's vast conglomerate includes everything from candy and carpets to railroads and running shoes. This weekend, they're all under one roof.. Warren Buffett has always known how to make a buck.
